a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n < 10 \<longrightarrow> f n = n + 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n >= 10 \<longrightarrow> f n = f (n - 5)"
shows  "(GREATEST n. \<exists> x. f x = n) = 19"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The function $f$ is defined on positive integers as follows:
\[f(n) = \left\{
\begin{array}{cl}
n + 10 & \text{if $n < 10$}, \\
f(n - 5) & \text{if $n \ge 10$}.
\end{array}
\right.\]Find the maximum value of the function. The final Answer is 19
 ### Proof
 We see that $f(n) = n + 10$ for $n = 1,$ 2, 3, $\dots,$ 9. Then \begin{align} f(10) &= f(5) = 15, \\ f(11) &= f(6) = 16, \\ f(12) &= f(7) = 17, \\ f(13) &= f(8) = 18, \\ f(14) &= f(9) = 19, \\ f(15) &= f(10) = 15, \end{align}and so on.
 At this point, the function becomes periodic, with period 5.
 Therefore, the maximum value of the function is $\boxed{19}.$
 *)

 *)
